heroSection.title: Create a methodology on Regen Registry.
heroSection.description: We are working hard to promote integrity and innovation in the methods used to monitor ecosystems and invite any and all methodology designers to take part in expanding this body of work.

stepCardSection.title: General process for creating a new methodology
stepCardSection.mainDescription: A lot can go into writing a new methodology and it might seem like an overwhelming process, but we’re here to help! Check out our CarbonPlus Grasslands Methodology to get a feel for what a methodology might entail and the various components included, and feel free to email science@regen.network for any additional questions.
stepCardSection.bottomTitle: Help develop a range of methodologies for the diversity of nature based solutions
stepCardSection.bottomDescription: In addition to developing methodologies focused on carbon reduction and removal, we must also work to incorporate protocols to track water cycles, nutrient cycles, biodiversity, pollution management, changing weather patterns, and more.

stepCards.title: Check if there is an approved methodology listed on one of the accepted programs
stepCards.description: Prior to developing a methodology, take a look to see if there is a similar methodology that is already approved on our program or other accepted programs. View our list of accepted programs»

stepCards.title: Generate an idea for a methodology and submit a concept note for internal review
stepCards.description: A concept note is a short proposal of an idea for a project or methodology which could be used to address environmental and societal challenges and provide human well-being and ecological benefits.

faqs.question: What to include in your concept note?
faqs.answer: We invite you to share your idea for a nature based solution and we can work together to refine it. Your concept note can include the management activities your concept applies to (cover cropping, rotational grazing, etc.), a high level summary of the indicators being measured, and the monitoring approach.

faqs.question: Where to start:
faqs.answer: Methodology Concept Note Template

stepCards.title: Create a methodology draft and submit it for internal review
stepCards.description: Your methodology should aim to outline standards and tools to monitor the ecological, environmental, and social indicators covered by your nature based solution. Your approach can be region specific or cover a wide range of locations.

faqs.question: What is the internal review process?
faqs.answer: Upon submission, the Regen Network Science Team will conduct an initial review to ensure all the proper information for monitoring, reporting, and verification (MRV) is included in your methodology. Feedback with suggested upgrades to your methodology will be provided after which the method will be accepted in beta form.

faqs.question: How complete does my draft need to be?
faqs.answer: The draft should include all the information needed for the MRV, however this process can also be used as an opportunity to work with the science community to refine your ideas and develop tools.

stepCards.title: Methodology accepted in beta form
stepCards.description: Methodologies that exist in beta form have not undergone any external review by experts or community members.

faqs.question: Can you run projects in beta form?
faqs.answer: The draft should include all the information needed for the MRV, however this process can also be used as an opportunity to work with the science community to refine your ideas and develop tools.

faqs.question: How does a methodology move out of the beta form?
faqs.answer: Methodologies move out of beta form after a scientific peer review. See step 5 for more details.

stepCards.title: Scientific peer review and public comment, updates made to beta methodology
stepCards.description: After internal review, it may be recommended that some methods undergo external review to ensure the methodology is supported by the scientific community. See our Methodology Review Process for more information.

faqs.question: How long does a scientific peer review take?
faqs.answer: The timeline for scientific peer review can vary. It is up to the methodology designer to drive the peer review process, however we expect this process to take anywhere from one and a half to two months depending on the speed of the reviewers.

faqs.question: What is the public comment period?
faqs.answer: The public comment period consists of a 30 day time period, where your method is opened up for review by community members who can submit comments, questions and feedback.

faqs.question: Can public comment and peer review happen concurrently?
faqs.answer: Yes, these two processes can be run in parallel.

stepCards.title: Methodology accepted!
stepCards.description: Once it has been confirmed that the methodology developer has addressed each comment or revision request, the methodology will be accepted and move out of its beta form.

peerReviewSection.title: Participate in Methodology Peer Review
peerReviewSection.description: Methodologies submitted to Regen Network will go through a review process to provide valuable feedback which can be used to improve our understanding of the science and techniques/approaches, while promoting scientific transparency and instilling buyer assurance and confidence in claims. This process is in place to promote best practices in MRV and foster both innovation and trust. If you are interested in reviewing methodologies that have been submitted, please contact us at <a href="mailto:science@regen.network">science@regen.network.</a

createCreditClassSection.title: Create a Credit Class
createCreditClassSection.description: If you haven’t yet created a credit class for this methodology, learn more below.

heroBannerTop.title: Learn more about our methodology review process.
heroBannerTop.description: Methodologies submitted to Regen Registry will undergo a scientific review process to support the adoption of best practices for the monitoring, reporting, and verification of nature based solutions. This process is a great opportunity to work with the scientific community to develop your methodology in a way that fosters innovation and trust.

internalReviewSection.title: Part 1: Internal Review
internalReviewSection.description:
Methodologies submitted to Regen Network Development Inc. will pass through an internal review process to ensure that all the components needed to monitor a nature based solution are included. If your methodology is missing important information needed for the monitoring, reporting and verification, we may ask you to make some upgrades and resubmit. Otherwise your methodology will be accepted in beta form on our website! 

 If you are creating a Flex Methodology, then only an internal review is required.
internalReviewSection.disclaimerBottom: *All time frames are estimations that may vary

externalReviewSection.title: Part 2: External Review Process
externalReviewSection.description: The external review process consists of A) a public comment period and B) a formal scientific peer review where members of the science community and experts in the field can provide feedback on a methodology. The two processes can be run in parallel, and provide methodology designers with the opportunity to address critiques and improve the science backing their methods.
externalReviewSection.disclaimerBottom: *All time frames are estimations that may vary

stepCards.title: Methodology opened on Regen Registry for a 30-day public comment period
stepCards.description: The public comment period is an opportunity for the scientific community to ask questions and provide feedback on a methodology. Questions and comments are compiled into a Feedback Document which is returned to the Methodology Developer.

stepCards.title: Methodology Developer compiles a Revision Report & upgrades methodology
stepCards.description: The Revision Report is an opportunity for the methodology developer to address comments, questions, and revision requests outlined in the public comment or scientific peer review process. The report includes answers to clarifying questions, indications of how comments or revision requests were incorporated into the updated methodology, or explanations of why the comment or revision request was not incorporated.

stepCards.title: Step 1: Scientific advisors review the methodology
stepCards.description: The Methodology Developer identifies a minimum of three scientific advisors which have appropriate training, background, knowledge and qualifications to provide an in-depth review of the submitted methodology. Scientific advisors will review the methodology and provide the Methodology Developer with a Feedback Document with all their comments, questions and revision requests.

stepCards.title: The Methodology Developer compiles a Revision Report
stepCards.description: The Revision Report is an opportunity for the methodology developer to address comments, questions, and revision requests outlined in the public comment or scientific peer review process. The report includes answers to clarifying questions, indications of how comments or revision requests were incorporated into the updated methodology, or explanations of why the comment or revision request was not incorporated.

stepCards.title: Regen Registry rejects or accepts the methodology
stepCards.description: The Methodology Developer submits the Revision Report to Regen Registry. If Regen Registry confirms that the Revision Report completes the requirements, it will be posted alongside the methodology (which moves out of beta version) and made publicly available. If Regen Registry rejects the methodology, full evaluation documentation will be provided.
